{ "user_query": "Apple finance summary", "conversation_key": "recent-83a0-ada7-a133-1dfa", "history_dump": "[{\"conversation_id\":null,\"query\":\"Apple finance summary\",\"chat_history\":\"\",\"conversation_key\":null,\"is_sql\":true,\"ques_id\":\"9244-42ba\",\"category\":\"PUB_DOC\",\"sub_category\":\"SEC_FIL\",\"doc_types\":\"\",\"is_citation\":false,\"ticker\":\"\",\"type\":\"sent\",\"reqTime\":\"2025-11-12T11:10:17.983Z\",\"isShowMore\":false},{\"thinkingText\":\"Fetching Publicly Listed Company Details\\nFetching SEC Filing Details of Publicly Listed Companies\\nFetching SEC Filing Details of Publicly Listed Companies\\nFetching Data from SEC Filings...\\nGenerating citations...\",\"data\":\"# Apple Inc. (AAPL) – Finance Summary Based on SEC Filings (FY2025 & FY2024)\\n\\n## Company Overview\\n\\nApple Inc. is a global technology company that designs, manufactures, and markets smartphones, computers, tablets, wearables, and a range of services and digital content. Its primary products include iPhone, Mac, iPad, and wearables such as Apple Watch and AirPods. The company also generates significant revenue from services like the App Store, Apple Music, iCloud, and AppleCare, as well as payment and subscription platforms (including Apple Pay and Apple Card). Apple serves a diverse customer base in consumer, business, education, enterprise, and government markets, distributing through direct retail, online channels, and indirect third-party partners[1].\\n\\n## Financial Performance\\nFiscal years for Apple Inc. end on the last Saturday of September, resulting in FY2025 closing on September 27, 2025, and FY2024 on September 28, 2024.\\n\\n### Key Metrics (USD, in millions):\\n\\n| Metric | FY2025 (Ended Sep 27, 2025) | FY2024 (Ended Sep 28, 2024) |\\n|--------------------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|\\n| Net Sales (Total) | $416,161 | $391,035 |\\n| - Products | $307,003 | $294,866 |\\n| - Services | $109,158 | $96,169 |\\n| Gross Margin | $195,201 | $180,683 |\\n| Operating Income | $133,050 | $123,216 |\\n| Net Income | $112,010 | $93,736 |\\n| Diluted EPS | $7.46 | $6.08 |\\n\\n*Fiscal years vary by company; see above for specific period end-dates.*[2][3]\\n\\n#### Performance Highlights:\\n- **Revenue Growth:** Apple’s net sales increased year-over-year, primarily driven by both growth in products (notably iPhone, Mac, and iPad lines) and robust expansion in services (App Store, digital subscriptions, etc.)[4].\\n- **Profitability:** Both gross margin and net income rose in FY2025, reflecting improved operational efficiency and a continued shift toward higher-margin services.\\n- **Shareholder Returns:** The company continued significant stock buybacks and dividends, with dividends per share at $1.02 in FY2025 and $0.98 in FY2024[5].\\n\\n## Revenue Streams & Business Segments\\n\\nApple segments its business primarily on a geographic basis — Americas, Europe, Greater China, Japan, and Rest of Asia Pacific — but its revenue streams are consistently distributed between products and services. Product net sales are especially driven by the iPhone, while services have seen continued growth from App Store, cloud, and subscription offerings[6].\\n\\n## Strategic Initiatives and Risks\\n\\n- **Innovation Focus:** Apple invests heavily in R&D (over $34.5 billion in FY2025) to maintain its competitive edge in hardware and services.\\n- **Service Diversification:** Rapid expansion in digital content, payment, fitness, and cloud services drive recurring revenue and higher margins.\\n- **Global Risks:** Apple highlights competitive pressure (notably imitation and aggressive pricing by competitors), supply chain complexity, and regulatory changes (including data privacy and evolving global laws) as key risks[7][8].\\n\\n## Cash Flows & Balance Sheet\\n\\n- **Operating Cash Flow:** Remained strong, exceeding $111 billion in FY2025.\\n- **Capital Return:** Substantial repurchases of common stock and a stable dividend policy characterize Apple’s ongoing commitment to returning value to shareholders[9].\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Summary\\n\\nApple Inc. remains a global leader in consumer technology with robust revenue growth, increasing profitability, and a growing reliance on high-margin services. Despite fierce competition and macroeconomic uncertainty, its commitment to innovation, operational excellence, and diversified offerings positions it well for future growth.\\n\\n*All data and insights above are sourced directly from Apple Inc.’s FY2025 and FY2024 10-K SEC filings.*\\n\\n\\n\\n #### References: \\n\\n-

AAPL_10-K_FY2025.pdf - P.5 [1] , P.33 [2] [4] , P.36 [5] , P.10 [7] , P.16 [8] , P.37 [9]

\\n-

AAPL_10-K_2024.pdf - P.32 [3] , P.5 [6]

\\n

Advertising The Company's advertising services include third-party\\nlicensing arrangements and the Company's own advertising platforms AppleCare\\nThe Company offers a portfolio of fee-based service and support products under\\nthe AppleCare brand The offerings provide priority access to Apple technical\\nsupport, access to the global Apple authorized service network for repair and\\nreplacement services, and in many cases additional coverage for instances of\\naccidental damage or theft and loss, depending on the country and type of\\nproduct Cloud Services The Company's cloud services store and keep customers'\\ncontent up-to-date and available across multiple Apple devices and Windows\\npersonal computers Digital Content The Company operates various platforms,\\nincluding the App Store (AAPL) – Finance Summary Based on SEC Filings (FY2025 & FY2024)\\\\n\\\\n## Company Overview\\\\n\\\\nApple Inc. is a global technology company that designs, manufactures, and markets smartphones, computers, tablets, wearables, and a range of services and digital content. Its primary products include iPhone, Mac, iPad, and wearables such as Apple Watch and AirPods. The company also generates significant revenue from services like the App Store, Apple Music, iCloud, and AppleCare, as well as payment and subscription platforms (including Apple Pay and Apple Card). Apple serves a diverse customer base in consumer, business, education, enterprise, and government markets, distributing through direct retail, online channels, and indirect third-party partners[1].\\\\n\\\\n## Financial Performance\\\\nFiscal years for Apple Inc. end on the last Saturday of September, resulting in FY2025 closing on September 27, 2025, and FY2024 on September 28, 2024.\\\\n\\\\n### Key Metrics (USD, in millions):\\\\n\\\\n| Metric | FY2025 (Ended Sep 27, 2025) | FY2024 (Ended Sep 28, 2024) |\\\\n|--------------------------|-----------------------------|-----------------------------|\\\\n| Net Sales (Total) | $416,161 | $391,035 |\\\\n| - Products | $307,003 | $294,866 |\\\\n| - Services | $109,158 | $96,169 |\\\\n| Gross Margin | $195,201 | $180,683 |\\\\n| Operating Income | $133,050 | $123,216 |\\\\n| Net Income | $112,010 | $93,736 |\\\\n| Diluted EPS | $7.46 | $6.08 |\\\\n\\\\n*Fiscal years vary by company; see above for specific period end-dates.*[2][3]\\\\n\\\\n#### Performance Highlights:\\\\n- **Revenue Growth:** Apple’s net sales increased year-over-year, primarily driven by both growth in products (notably iPhone, Mac, and iPad lines) and robust expansion in services (App Store, digital subscriptions, etc.)[4].\\\\n- **Profitability:** Both gross margin and net income rose in FY2025, reflecting improved operational efficiency and a continued shift toward higher-margin services.\\\\n- **Shareholder Returns:** The company continued significant stock buybacks and dividends, with dividends per share at $1.02 in FY2025 and $0.98 in FY2024[5].\\\\n\\\\n## Revenue Streams & Business Segments\\\\n\\\\nApple segments its business primarily on a geographic basis — Americas, Europe, Greater China, Japan, and Rest of Asia Pacific — but its revenue streams are consistently distributed between products and services. Product net sales are especially driven by the iPhone, while services have seen continued growth from App Store, cloud, and subscription offerings[6].\\\\n\\\\n## Strategic Initiatives and Risks\\\\n\\\\n- **Innovation Focus:** Apple invests heavily in R&D (over $34.5 billion in FY2025) to maintain its competitive edge in hardware and services.\\\\n- **Service Diversification:** Rapid expansion in digital content, payment, fitness, and cloud services drive recurring revenue and higher margins.\\\\n- **Global Risks:** Apple highlights competitive pressure (notably imitation and aggressive pricing by competitors), supply chain complexity, and regulatory changes (including data privacy and evolving global laws) as key risks[7][8].\\\\n\\\\n## Cash Flows & Balance Sheet\\\\n\\\\n- **Operating Cash Flow:** Remained strong, exceeding $111 billion in FY2025.\\\\n- **Capital Return:** Substantial repurchases of common stock and a stable dividend policy characterize Apple’s ongoing commitment to returning value to shareholders[9].\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### Summary\\\\n\\\\nApple Inc. remains a global leader in consumer technology with robust revenue growth, increasing profitability, and a growing reliance on high-margin services. Despite fierce competition and macroeconomic uncertainty, its commitment to innovation, operational excellence, and diversified offerings positions it well for future growth.\\\\n\\\\n*All data and insights above are sourced directly from Apple Inc.’s FY2025 and FY2024 10-K SEC filings.*\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n #### References: \\\\n\\\\n-

applied to register, additional patents, trademarks and copyrights In contrast, many of the Company\'s competitors seek to compete primarily through aggressive pricing and very low cost structures, and by imitating the Company\'s products and infringing on its intellectual property Effective intellectual property protection is not consistently available in every country in which the Company operates If the Company is unable to continue to develop and sell innovative new products with attractive margins or if competitors infringe on the Company\'s intellectual property, the Company\'s ability to maintain a competitive advantage could be materially adversely affected The Company\'s products and services face substantial competition from companies that have significant technical, marketing, distribution and other resources, as well as established hardware, software and service offerings In addition, the Company faces significant competition as competitors imitate the Company\'s product features and applications within their products to offer more competitive solutions The Company also expects competition to intensify as competitors imitate the Company\'s approach to providing components seamlessly within their offerings or work collaboratively to offer integrated solutions Some of the Company\'s competitors have broad product lines, low-priced products, large installed bases of active devices, and large customer bases Competition has been particularly intense as competitors have aggressively cut prices and lowered product margins Certain competitors have the resources, experience or cost structures to provide products and services at little or no profit or even at a loss The Company has a minority market share in the global smartphone, personal computer, tablet and wearables markets, and some of the markets in which the Company competes have from time to time experienced little to no growth or contracted overall If the Company is unable to compete successfully, its business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be materially adversely affected Apple Inc | 2025 Form 10-K | { "user_query": "key impacts of KPMG", "conversation_key": "recent-26cc-a29c-7a8f-ad6e", "history_dump": "[{\"conversation_id\":null,\"query\":\"key impacts of KPMG\",\"chat_history\":\"\",\"conversation_key\":null,\"is_sql\":true,\"ques_id\":\"348c-f7e5\",\"category\":\"PUB_DOC\",\"sub_category\":\"GUID\",\"doc_types\":\"GUID\",\"asc_section\":\"\",\"file_ids\":\"\",\"issued_by\":\"\",\"is_citation\":false,\"type\":\"sent\",\"reqTime\":\"2025-11-12T11:13:20.429Z\",\"isShowMore\":false},{\"thinkingText\":\"Get Valid Filters for Guidance Documents\\nSearching Guidance Documents\\nGenerating citations...\",\"data\":\"Here are the key impacts highlighted in KPMG's authoritative accounting and regulatory guidance, drawing from their recent publications:\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 1. Transition to New Standards (e.g., ASC 606 — Revenue Recognition)\\n\\n- **System & Process Changes**: KPMG stresses that the choice of transition option (full or modified retrospective) will have a significant impact on the extent and timing of changes to systems and processes. Organizations need to plan early, perform gap analyses, and ensure that both quantitative and qualitative effects are understood and addressed[1].\\n- **Internal Controls**: Adopting new standards requires robust internal controls to ensure the completeness and accuracy of new information—especially before year-end certifications such as Sarbanes-Oxley[2].\\n- **Disclosures Expansion**: KPMG notes the new standards typically result in substantially more extensive disclosure requirements, impacting core systems that feed quantitative disclosures[3].\\n- **Comparability & KPIs**: Adoption may lead to non-comparable results between periods, impacting management metrics (such as KPIs and compensation). This may drive a preference for certain transition methods for better period-to-period comparability[4].\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 2. Leases (ASC 842) – Economic and Operational Complexities\\n\\n- **Applying Related Standards**: KPMG details challenges in applying other standards (like Topic 360 for impairment or Topic 420 for exit and disposal costs) to lease assets recognized for the first time under ASC 842. Recent economic events (COVID-19, inflation, new working models) intensify the complexity and may result in additional impairments or abandonments[5].\\n- **Transition Methods**: KPMG’s guidance helps navigate the complexities of which transition option (effective date vs. comparative transition method) is appropriate, with tailored advice for public and private companies.[6]\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 3. Credit Impairment (ASC 326)\\n\\n- **Disclosure Requirements**: KPMG highlights that even if quantitative impacts of new standards cannot be fully estimated, companies are encouraged to provide detailed qualitative disclosures that inform investors about the expected significance and implementation timeline. These disclosures should evolve and expand as the effective date approaches and as implementation progresses[7].\\n- **Resource Allocation**: Sufficient resources and specialized competencies are necessary for timely and accurate implementation, and delays should be disclosed and explained[8].\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 4. Fair Value Measurement (ASC 820/IFRS 13)\\n\\n- **Judgment & Uncertainty**: KPMG advises that companies must regularly reevaluate the assumptions and inputs used in fair value measurement, especially during periods of economic volatility. Clear, comprehensive disclosures around estimation uncertainty and the rationale for methodologies used are critical to informing users[9].\\n- **Dynamic Guidance**: Their handbooks and resources are regularly updated to reflect not only FASB/IASB rule changes but also market practice and regulatory expectations[10].\\n\\n---\\n\\n### 5. General Themes Across KPMG Guidance\\n\\n- **Advance Planning**: Across all standards, KPMG’s key message is to start early, carefully assess impacts and ensure both technical and operational readiness.\\n- **Focus on Stakeholder Communication**: Both the technical nature and business/practical impacts of adoption should be discussed openly with key stakeholders, including audit committees and investors.\\n- **Continuous Disclosure Evolution**: Disclosures should become increasingly detailed, reflecting new insights and updated estimates as implementation matures.\\n\\n---\\n\\n**Summary**: \\nKPMG’s guidance emphasizes that adopting new FASB and IFRS standards has wide-ranging financial, operational, and reporting impacts. Key impacts include the need for robust transition plans, enhanced disclosures, revised internal controls, reassessment of management metrics, proactive resource allocation, and ongoing stakeholder engagement—all tailored to the company's unique circumstances and latest market conditions.\\n\\nLet me know if you need a deep dive into the key impacts of a specific standard or business process in KPMG’s guidance.\\n\\n\\n\\n #### References: \\n\\n-

201606 KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf - P.39 [1] , P.37 [2] [4]

\\n-

201605 KPMG Illustrative Disclosures - Revenue.pdf - P.3 [3]

\\n-

202301 KPMG HT Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions.pdf - P.1 [5] , P.8 [6]

\\n-

202301 KPMG Handbook Credit Impairment.pdf - P.439 [7]

\\n-

201710 KPMG Credit Impairment Handbook.pdf - P.310 [8]

\\n-

202311 KPMG Handbook Fair value measurement.pdf - P.3 [9] , P.170 [10]

\\n

KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\",\"page_no\":39,\"quote\":\"Home 6 Next steps The choice of transition option will have a significant\\nimpact on the extent and timing of system and process changes, and should be\\nconsidered as soon as possible We recommend that entities consider both the\\nquantitative effects of each method and the relevant qualitative factors\\nAdvance planning will allow time for unanticipated complexities, and will\\noffer greater flexibility in maximizing the use of internal resources by\\nspreading the required work over a longer period Entities should therefore\\ntake steps to understand the new standard and to evaluate the effects of the\\ntransition options on their financial reporting Some entities may quickly\\ndecide that the impacts are minimal, in which case it may be appropriate to\\nwait longer to evaluate the transition options However, others will be faced\\nwith substantial impacts requiring major effort, and should therefore start\\nplanning as soon as possible Entities should consider completing the following\\nactions – Perform a high-level gap analysis to identify potential drivers of\\nchanges in accounting for revenue and certain costs – Determine the population\\nof contracts that may need to be restated This may include identifying any\\nindividually significant contracts that should be assessed separately, or sub-\\npopulations of contracts with similar characteristics that can be evaluated in\\nthe aggregate – Begin assessing the information that will be needed to comply\\nwith the new standard Compare this with currently available information to\\nidentify potential gaps that should be considered in the broader\\nimplementation of the new standard – Identify the qualitative factors that may\\ninfluence your choice of transition option Key stakeholders may need to be\\nengaged to understand which factors are most relevant – Ensure that transition\\noptions are evaluated in conjunction with the broader implementation effort\\nfor the new standard Consider implementing a subgroup within the overall\\nproject team responsible for implementation, to focus on transition option\\nconsiderations – Develop an implementation plan The Appendix includes example\\ntransition project plans that highlight the key steps involved in undertaking\\na successful transition project\\n\\n\",\"quote_no\":1,\"bboxes\":[{\"x1\":36,\"y1\":29.5285701751709,\"x2\":576.0281982421875,\"y2\":785.7698974609375}]},{\"counter_number\":2,\"file_id\":\"GUIDEDOC-fbfd627e-9a36-4525-926a-ba7d2e201bba\",\"file_name\":\"201606 KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\",\"page_no\":37,\"quote\":\"2 Internal control considerations Regardless of the transition option elected,\\nentities will need adequate processes and controls to ensure that the\\ninformation used to comply with the new standard and transition requirements\\nis complete and accurate They may want to consider the cost and timeframe for\\ndesigning and implementing these processes and controls when choosing a\\ntransition method Some entities may want to implement their process and\\ncontrol changes before signing any certifications relating to internal control\\nunder Sarbanes-Oxley, so that they can be documented and tested, and any\\ndeficiencies addressed, before the year end\\n\\n\",\"quote_no\":1,\"bboxes\":[{\"x1\":187.39199829101562,\"y1\":240.86988830566406,\"x2\":572.0467529296875,\"y2\":396.0018005371094}]},{\"counter_number\":3,\"file_id\":\"GUIDEDOC-aa4cd4df-3202-4a92-8100-f772d46537b7\",\"file_name\":\"201605 KPMG Illustrative Disclosures - Revenue.pdf\",\"page_no\":3,\"quote\":\"Both public and private entities will be subject to extensive new disclosure\\nrequirements for financial reporting purposes In addition to affecting an\\nentity's internal controls and business processes around external financial\\nreporting, they will likely impact the core systems used to produce the\\nnumbers required in the quantitative disclosures\\n\\n\",\"quote_no\":1,\"bboxes\":[{\"x1\":74.125,\"y1\":327.39599609375,\"x2\":559.6917114257812,\"y2\":401.8680114746094}]},{\"counter_number\":4,\"file_id\":\"GUIDEDOC-fbfd627e-9a36-4525-926a-ba7d2e201bba\",\"file_name\":\"201606 KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\",\"page_no\":37,\"quote\":\"2 Internal reporting Significant changes in the amount or timing of revenue\\nand earnings could lead to changes in key performance indicators (KPIs) or\\nother metrics used to communicate financial results Management compensation\\nmetrics may also be affected or need to be adjusted for the transition impact\\nIf applying the new standard creates a lack of comparability against\\npreviously used metrics, or results in the need to use different metrics or to\\nadjust previous metrics, then it may be beneficial to use the retrospective\\nmethod because it provides greater comparability across all periods presented\\nin the financial statements\\n\\n\",\"quote_no\":1,\"bboxes\":[{\"x1\":177.7779998779297,\"y1\":572.5806274414062,\"x2\":569.6907958984375,\"y2\":724.377685546875}]},{\"counter_number\":5,\"file_id\":\"GUIDEDOC-01039dcc-ea7c-4527-86af-b66e28156f89\",\"file_name\":\"202301 KPMG HT Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions.pdf\",\"page_no\":1,\"quote\":\"Hot Topic: Leases | 1 Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions Existing Topic 420 liabilities and the initial application of Topic 360 to ROU assets add complexity for lessees transitioning to Topic 842 Public companies generally adopted Topic 842 (leases) in 2019 In those implementations we observed companies experience some challenges with: • applying Topic 360 (property, plant and equipment) impairment and abandonment requirements to previously unrecognized operating lease right-of-use (ROU) assets; and • understanding how Topic 420 (exit and disposal costs), which previously applied to operating leases under the legacy leases guidance (Topic 840), applies to those leases under and in transition to Topic 842 These challenges may be even more acute for private entities adopting and reporting under Topic 842 for the first time now or in the near term This is because the economic events and conditions of the last few years – e g COVID-19, inflation, rising interest rates and new hybrid or remote working models – may have given rise to new Topic 360 impairments or abandonments or new accounting events under Topic 420 In addition to any long-lived assets impaired or abandoned under Topic 360 during this period, these events and conditions may also have given rise to impairments or abandonments of operating lease ROU assets had Topic 840 required their recognition KPMG Handbook, Leases, provides guidance on: • applying Topic 360 to existing leases in transition to Topic 842; • accounting for existing, lease-related Topic 420 liabilities in transition to Topic 842; and • considering applicability of Topic 420 to lease arrangements after Topic 842 adoption This Hot Topic compiles specific Questions on these topics from the Handbook (retaining their numbering) into one concise document to assist entities in their initial application of Topic 842 Given the small number of entities that have adopted, or that we expect to adopt, Topic 842 using the 'comparative transition method' (discussed in Chapter 13B of the Handbook), only the Questions and Examples related to adopting Topic 842 using the 'effective date transition method' (included in Chapter 13A of the Handbook) have been reproduced in this Hot Topic The questions included in this Hot Topic may not address all of the issues a lessee could encounter on these topics when transitioning to Topic 842 We encourage entities to discuss these issues with their auditors or other accounting KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\",\"page_no\":39,\"quote\":\"Home 6 Next steps The choice of transition option will have a significant\\nimpact on the extent and timing of system and process changes, and should be\\nconsidered as soon as possible We recommend that entities consider both the\\nquantitative effects of each method and the relevant qualitative factors\\nAdvance planning will allow time for unanticipated complexities, and will\\noffer greater flexibility in maximizing the use of internal resources by\\nspreading the required work over a longer period Entities should therefore\\ntake steps to understand the new standard and to evaluate the effects of the\\ntransition options on their financial reporting Some entities may quickly\\ndecide that the impacts are minimal, in which case it may be appropriate to\\nwait longer to evaluate the transition options However, others will be faced\\nwith substantial impacts requiring major effort, and should therefore start\\nplanning as soon as possible Entities should consider completing the following\\nactions – Perform a high-level gap analysis to identify potential drivers of\\nchanges in accounting for revenue and certain costs – Determine the population\\nof contracts that may need to be restated This may include identifying any\\nindividually significant contracts that should be assessed separately, or sub-\\npopulations of contracts with similar characteristics that can be evaluated in\\nthe aggregate – Begin assessing the information that will be needed to comply\\nwith the new standard Compare this with currently available information to\\nidentify potential gaps that should be considered in the broader\\nimplementation of the new standard – Identify the qualitative factors that may\\ninfluence your choice of transition option Key stakeholders may need to be\\nengaged to understand which factors are most relevant – Ensure that transition\\noptions are evaluated in conjunction with the broader implementation effort\\nfor the new standard Consider implementing a subgroup within the overall\\nproject team responsible for implementation, to focus on transition option\\nconsiderations – Develop an implementation plan The Appendix includes example\\ntransition project plans that highlight the key steps involved in undertaking\\na successful transition KPMG Illustrative Disclosures - Revenue.pdf\",\"type\":\"GUID\"},{\"counter_number\":5,\"file_id\":\"GUIDEDOC-01039dcc-ea7c-4527-86af-b66e28156f89\",\"file_name\":\"202301 KPMG HT Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions.pdf\",\"page_no\":1,\"quote\":\"Hot Topic: Leases | 1 Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions Existing Topic 420 liabilities and the initial application of Topic 360 to ROU assets add complexity for lessees transitioning to Topic 842 Public companies generally adopted Topic 842 (leases) in 2019 In those implementations we observed companies experience some challenges with: • applying Topic 360 (property, plant and equipment) impairment and abandonment requirements to previously unrecognized operating lease right-of-use (ROU) assets; and • understanding how Topic 420 (exit and disposal costs), which previously applied to operating leases under the legacy leases guidance (Topic 840), applies to those leases under and in transition to Topic 842 These challenges may be even more acute for private entities adopting and reporting under Topic 842 for the first time now or in the near term This is because the economic events and conditions of the last few years – e g COVID-19, inflation, rising interest rates and new hybrid or remote working models – may have given rise to new Topic 360 impairments or abandonments or new accounting events under Topic 420 In addition to any long-lived assets impaired or abandoned under Topic 360 during this period, these events and conditions may also have given rise to impairments or abandonments of operating lease ROU assets had Topic 840 required their recognition KPMG Handbook, Leases, provides guidance on: • applying Topic 360 to existing leases in transition to Topic 842; • accounting for existing, lease-related Topic 420 liabilities in transition to Topic 842; and • considering applicability of Topic 420 to lease arrangements after Topic 842 adoption This Hot Topic compiles specific Questions on these topics from the Handbook (retaining their numbering) into one concise document to assist entities in their initial application of Topic 842 Given the small number of entities that have adopted, or that we expect to adopt, Topic 842 using the 'comparative transition method' (discussed in Chapter 13B of the Handbook), only the Questions and Examples related to adopting Topic 842 using the 'effective date transition method' (included in Chapter 13A of the Handbook) have been reproduced in this Hot Topic The questions included in this Hot Topic may not address all of the issues a lessee could encounter on these topics when transitioning to Topic 842 We encourage entities to discuss these issues with their auditors or other accounting advisors\\n\\n\",\"quote_no\":1,\"bboxes\":[{\"x1\":71.98234558105469,\"y1\":73.55998229980469,\"x2\":539.6085815429688,\"y2\":764.2620239257812}],\"citations\":[{\"file_name\":\"202301 KPMG HT Topic Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/141.0.0.0 Safari/537.36' \ -H 'x-request-id: f26b8ec2-ff05-48aa-b0a0-637454bbd681' \ --data-raw $'{"user_query":"key impacts of KPMG","conversation_key":"recent-26cc-a29c-7a8f-ad6e","history_dump":"[{\\"conversation_id\\":null,\\"query\\":\\"key impacts of KPMG\\",\\"chat_history\\":\\"\\",\\"conversation_key\\":null,\\"is_sql\\":true,\\"ques_id\\":\\"348c-f7e5\\",\\"category\\":\\"PUB_DOC\\",\\"sub_category\\":\\"GUID\\",\\"doc_types\\":\\"GUID\\",\\"asc_section\\":\\"\\",\\"file_ids\\":\\"\\",\\"issued_by\\":\\"\\",\\"is_citation\\":false,\\"type\\":\\"sent\\",\\"reqTime\\":\\"2025-11-12T11:13:20.429Z\\",\\"isShowMore\\":false},{\\"thinkingText\\":\\"Get Valid Filters for Guidance Documents\\\\nSearching Guidance Documents\\\\nGenerating citations...\\",\\"data\\":\\"Here are the key impacts highlighted in KPMG\'s authoritative accounting and regulatory guidance, drawing from their recent publications:\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### 1. Transition to New Standards (e.g., ASC 606 — Revenue Recognition)\\\\n\\\\n- **System & Process Changes**: KPMG stresses that the choice of transition option (full or modified retrospective) will have a significant impact on the extent and timing of changes to systems and processes. Organizations need to plan early, perform gap analyses, and ensure that both quantitative and qualitative effects are understood and addressed[1].\\\\n- **Internal Controls**: Adopting new standards requires robust internal controls to ensure the completeness and accuracy of new information—especially before year-end certifications such as Sarbanes-Oxley[2].\\\\n- **Disclosures Expansion**: KPMG notes the new standards typically result in substantially more extensive disclosure requirements, impacting core systems that feed quantitative disclosures[3].\\\\n- **Comparability & KPIs**: Adoption may lead to non-comparable results between periods, impacting management metrics (such as KPIs and compensation). This may drive a preference for certain transition methods for better period-to-period comparability[4].\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### 2. Leases (ASC 842) – Economic and Operational Complexities\\\\n\\\\n- **Applying Related Standards**: KPMG details challenges in applying other standards (like Topic 360 for impairment or Topic 420 for exit and disposal costs) to lease assets recognized for the first time under ASC 842. Recent economic events (COVID-19, inflation, new working models) intensify the complexity and may result in additional impairments or abandonments[5].\\\\n- **Transition Methods**: KPMG’s guidance helps navigate the complexities of which transition option (effective date vs. comparative transition method) is appropriate, with tailored advice for public and private companies.[6]\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### 3. Credit Impairment (ASC 326)\\\\n\\\\n- **Disclosure Requirements**: KPMG highlights that even if quantitative impacts of new standards cannot be fully estimated, companies are encouraged to provide detailed qualitative disclosures that inform investors about the expected significance and implementation timeline. These disclosures should evolve and expand as the effective date approaches and as implementation progresses[7].\\\\n- **Resource Allocation**: Sufficient resources and specialized competencies are necessary for timely and accurate implementation, and delays should be disclosed and explained[8].\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### 4. Fair Value Measurement (ASC 820/IFRS 13)\\\\n\\\\n- **Judgment & Uncertainty**: KPMG advises that companies must regularly reevaluate the assumptions and inputs used in fair value measurement, especially during periods of economic volatility. Clear, comprehensive disclosures around estimation uncertainty and the rationale for methodologies used are critical to informing users[9].\\\\n- **Dynamic Guidance**: Their handbooks and resources are regularly updated to reflect not only FASB/IASB rule changes but also market practice and regulatory expectations[10].\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### 5. General Themes Across KPMG Guidance\\\\n\\\\n- **Advance Planning**: Across all standards, KPMG’s key message is to start early, carefully assess impacts and ensure both technical and operational readiness.\\\\n- **Focus on Stakeholder Communication**: Both the technical nature and business/practical impacts of adoption should be discussed openly with key stakeholders, including audit committees and investors.\\\\n- **Continuous Disclosure Evolution**: Disclosures should become increasingly detailed, reflecting new insights and updated estimates as implementation matures.\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n**Summary**: \\\\nKPMG’s guidance emphasizes that adopting new FASB and IFRS standards has wide-ranging financial, operational, and reporting impacts. Key impacts include the need for robust transition plans, enhanced disclosures, revised internal controls, reassessment of management metrics, proactive resource allocation, and ongoing stakeholder engagement—all tailored to the company\'s unique circumstances and latest market conditions.\\\\n\\\\nLet me know if you need a deep dive into the key impacts of a specific standard or business process in KPMG’s guidance.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n #### References: \\\\n\\\\n-

KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":39,\\"quote\\":\\"Home 6 Next steps The choice of transition option will have a significant\\\\nimpact on the extent and timing of system and process changes, and should be\\\\nconsidered as soon as possible We recommend that entities consider both the\\\\nquantitative effects of each method and the relevant qualitative factors\\\\nAdvance planning will allow time for unanticipated complexities, and will\\\\noffer greater flexibility in maximizing the use of internal resources by\\\\nspreading the required work over a longer period Entities should therefore\\\\ntake steps to understand the new standard and to evaluate the effects of the\\\\ntransition options on their financial reporting Some entities may quickly\\\\ndecide that the impacts are minimal, in which case it may be appropriate to\\\\nwait longer to evaluate the transition options However, others will be faced\\\\nwith substantial impacts requiring major effort, and should therefore start\\\\nplanning as soon as possible Entities should consider completing the following\\\\nactions – Perform a high-level gap analysis to identify potential drivers of\\\\nchanges in accounting for revenue and certain costs – Determine the population\\\\nof contracts that may need to be restated This may include identifying any\\\\nindividually significant contracts that should be assessed separately, or sub-\\\\npopulations of contracts with similar characteristics that can be evaluated in\\\\nthe aggregate – Begin assessing the information that will be needed to comply\\\\nwith the new standard Compare this with currently available information to\\\\nidentify potential gaps that should be considered in the broader\\\\nimplementation of the new standard – Identify the qualitative factors that may\\\\ninfluence your choice of transition option Key stakeholders may need to be\\\\nengaged to understand which factors are most relevant – Ensure that transition\\\\noptions are evaluated in conjunction with the broader implementation effort\\\\nfor the new standard Consider implementing a subgroup within the overall\\\\nproject team responsible for implementation, to focus on transition option\\\\nconsiderations – Develop an implementation plan The Appendix includes example\\\\ntransition project plans that highlight the key steps involved in undertaking\\\\na successful transition project\\\\n\\\\n\\",\\"quote_no\\":1,\\"bboxes\\":[{\\"x1\\":36,\\"y1\\":29.5285701751709,\\"x2\\":576.0281982421875,\\"y2\\":785.7698974609375}]},{\\"counter_number\\":2,\\"file_id\\":\\"GUIDEDOC-fbfd627e-9a36-4525-926a-ba7d2e201bba\\",\\"file_name\\":\\"201606 KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":37,\\"quote\\":\\"2 Internal control considerations Regardless of the transition option elected,\\\\nentities will need adequate processes and controls to ensure that the\\\\ninformation used to comply with the new standard and transition requirements\\\\nis complete and accurate They may want to consider the cost and timeframe for\\\\ndesigning and implementing these processes and controls when choosing a\\\\ntransition method Some entities may want to implement their process and\\\\ncontrol changes before signing any certifications relating to internal control\\\\nunder Sarbanes-Oxley, so that they can be documented and tested, and any\\\\ndeficiencies addressed, before the year end\\\\n\\\\n\\",\\"quote_no\\":1,\\"bboxes\\":[{\\"x1\\":187.39199829101562,\\"y1\\":240.86988830566406,\\"x2\\":572.0467529296875,\\"y2\\":396.0018005371094}]},{\\"counter_number\\":3,\\"file_id\\":\\"GUIDEDOC-aa4cd4df-3202-4a92-8100-f772d46537b7\\",\\"file_name\\":\\"201605 KPMG Illustrative Disclosures - Revenue.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":3,\\"quote\\":\\"Both public and private entities will be subject to extensive new disclosure\\\\nrequirements for financial reporting purposes In addition to affecting an\\\\nentity\'s internal controls and business processes around external financial\\\\nreporting, they will likely impact the core systems used to produce the\\\\nnumbers required in the quantitative disclosures\\\\n\\\\n\\",\\"quote_no\\":1,\\"bboxes\\":[{\\"x1\\":74.125,\\"y1\\":327.39599609375,\\"x2\\":559.6917114257812,\\"y2\\":401.8680114746094}]},{\\"counter_number\\":4,\\"file_id\\":\\"GUIDEDOC-fbfd627e-9a36-4525-926a-ba7d2e201bba\\",\\"file_name\\":\\"201606 KPMG Revenue Transition Options - best for your business.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":37,\\"quote\\":\\"2 Internal reporting Significant changes in the amount or timing of revenue\\\\nand earnings could lead to changes in key performance indicators (KPIs) or\\\\nother metrics used to communicate financial results Management compensation\\\\nmetrics may also be affected or need to be adjusted for the transition impact\\\\nIf applying the new standard creates a lack of comparability against\\\\npreviously used metrics, or results in the need to use different metrics or to\\\\nadjust previous metrics, then it may be beneficial to use the retrospective\\\\nmethod because it provides greater comparability across all periods presented\\\\nin the financial statements\\\\n\\\\n\\",\\"quote_no\\":1,\\"bboxes\\":[{\\"x1\\":177.7779998779297,\\"y1\\":572.5806274414062,\\"x2\\":569.6907958984375,\\"y2\\":724.377685546875}]},{\\"counter_number\\":5,\\"file_id\\":\\"GUIDEDOC-01039dcc-ea7c-4527-86af-b66e28156f89\\",\\"file_name\\":\\"202301 KPMG HT Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":1,\\"quote\\":\\"Hot Topic: Leases | 1 Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions Existing Topic 420 liabilities and the initial application of Topic 360 to ROU assets add complexity for lessees transitioning to Topic 842 Public companies generally adopted Topic 842 (leases) in 2019 In those implementations we observed companies experience some challenges with: • applying Topic 360 (property, plant and equipment) impairment and abandonment requirements to previously unrecognized operating lease right-of-use (ROU) assets; and • understanding how Topic 420 (exit and disposal costs), which previously applied to operating leases under the legacy leases guidance (Topic 840), applies to those leases under and in transition to Topic 842 These challenges may be even more acute for private entities adopting and reporting under Topic 842 for the first time now or in the near term This is because the economic events and conditions of the last few years – e g COVID-19, inflation, rising interest rates and new hybrid or remote working models – may have given rise to new Topic 360 impairments or abandonments or new accounting events under Topic 420 In addition to any long-lived assets impaired or abandoned under Topic 360 during this period, these events and conditions may also have given rise to impairments or abandonments of operating lease ROU assets had Topic 840 required their recognition KPMG Handbook, Leases, provides guidance on: • applying Topic 360 to existing leases in transition to Topic 842; • accounting for existing, lease-related Topic 420 liabilities in transition to Topic 842; and • considering applicability of Topic 420 to lease arrangements after Topic 842 adoption This Hot Topic compiles specific Questions on these topics from the Handbook (retaining their numbering) into one concise document to assist entities in their initial application of Topic 842 Given the small number of entities that have adopted, or that we expect to adopt, Topic 842 using the \'comparative transition method\' (discussed in Chapter 13B of the Handbook), only the Questions and Examples related to adopting Topic 842 using the \'effective date transition method\' (included in Chapter 13A of the Handbook) have been reproduced in this Hot Topic The questions included in this Hot Topic may not address all of the issues a lessee could encounter on these topics when transitioning to Topic 842 We encourage entities to discuss these issues with their auditors or other accounting advisors\\\\n\\\\n\\",\\"quote_no\\":1,\\"bboxes\\":[{\\"x1\\":71.98234558105469,\\"y1\\":73.55998229980469,\\"x2\\":539.6085815429688,\\"y2\\":764.2620239257812}]},{\\"counter_number\\":6,\\"file_id\\":\\"GUIDEDOC-01039dcc-ea7c-4527-86af-b66e28156f89\\",\\"file_name\\":\\"202301 KPMG HT Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":8,\\"quote\\":\\"Hot Topic: Leases | 8 Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions For further information For more information about applying Topic 842, see KPMG Handbook, Leases Chapters 13A (effective date transition method) and 13B (comparative transition method) specifically discuss transition Section 6 5 discusses lease ROU asset impairment and abandonment and the interaction of Topic 420 and Topic 842 For more information on the Topic 360 impairment guidance, including considerations during a period of economic uncertainty, refer to KPMG Handbook, Impairment of nonfinancial assets, and the related KPMG Hot Topic, Impairment: Nonfinancial asset impairment in a period of economic uncertainty This document is part of a series to highlight implementation issues that are discussed in KPMG Handbook, Leases Contact us Scott Muir Partner smuir@kpmg com Robin Van Voorhies Senior Director redunn@kpmg com Corey Glidden Senior Manager cglidden@kpmg KPMG Handbook Credit Impairment.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":439,\\"quote\\":\\"— the date that adoption is required and the date that the registrant plans to\\\\nadopt, if earlier; — a discussion of the method of adoption; — a discussion of\\\\nthe effect that adoption of the standard is expected to have on the financial\\\\nstatements, unless not known or reasonably estimable In that case, a statement\\\\nto that effect may be made; and — the potential effect of other significant\\\\nmatters that the registrant believes may result from the adoption of the\\\\nstandard is encouraged – e g technical violations of debt covenant agreements,\\\\nplanned or intended changes in business practices If a registrant is not able\\\\nto reasonably estimate the effect Topic 326 will have on its financial\\\\nstatements, it should consider additional qualitative disclosures to assist\\\\nfinancial statement users in determining the significance of the Topic\'s\\\\neffect on its financial statements when adopted The SEC staff expects these\\\\nqualitative disclosures to include: 250-10-S99-6 — a description of the effect\\\\nof the accounting policies that the registrant expects to apply, if\\\\ndetermined, and a comparison with the current accounting policies; and — the\\\\nregistrant\'s progress in implementing the new standard and the significant\\\\nimplementation matters that it still needs to address The purpose of these\\\\ndisclosures is to ensure financial statement users understand the significance\\\\nof the effect that Topic 326 is expected to have on the registrant\'s financial\\\\nstatements, as well as a clear timeline for the expected implementation of the\\\\nstandard 250-10-S99-6 The SEC staff expects SAB 74 disclosures for new\\\\nstandards to become more detailed as the effective date approaches Therefore,\\\\neven if a registrant provides only qualitative disclosures because it is not\\\\nable to reasonably estimate the effect of Topic 326, it should augment its\\\\ndisclosures at each reporting date for any further relevant information\\\\nAdditionally, it should continue to modify any quantitative disclosures as its\\\\nestimates requiring major effort, and should therefore start\\\\nplanning as soon as possible Entities should consider completing the following\\\\nactions – Perform a high-level gap analysis to identify that will be needed to comply\\\\nwith the new standard Compare this with currently available information to\\\\nidentify potential gaps that should be considered in the broader\\\\nimplementation of 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions.pdf\\",\\"page_no\\":1,\\"quote\\":\\"Hot Topic: Leases | 1 Topic 842 transition complexities from recent economic conditions Existing Topic 420 liabilities and the initial application of Topic 360 to ROU assets add complexity for lessees transitioning to Topic 842 Public companies generally adopted Topic 842 (leases) in 2019 In those implementations we observed companies experience some challenges with: • applying Topic 360 (property, plant and equipment) impairment and abandonment requirements to previously unrecognized operating lease right-of-use (ROU) assets; and • understanding how Topic 420 (exit and disposal costs), which previously applied to operating leases under the legacy leases guidance (Topic 840), applies to those leases under and in transition to Topic 842 These challenges may be even more acute for private entities adopting and reporting under Topic 842 for the first time now or in the near term This is because the economic events and conditions of the last few years – e g COVID-19, inflation, rising interest rates and new hybrid or remote working models – may have given rise to new Topic 360 impairments or abandonments or new accounting events under Topic 420 In addition to any long-lived assets impaired or abandoned under Topic 360 during this period, these events and conditions may also have given rise to impairments or abandonments of operating lease ROU assets had Topic 840 required their recognition KPMG Handbook, Leases, provides guidance on: • applying Topic 360 to existing leases in transition to Topic 842; • accounting for existing, lease-related Topic 420 liabilities in transition to Topic 842; and • considering applicability of Topic 420 to lease arrangements after Topic 842 adoption This Hot Topic compiles specific Questions on these topics from the Handbook (retaining their numbering) into one concise document to assist entities in their initial application of Topic 842 Given the small number of entities that have adopted, or that we expect to adopt, Topic 842 using the \'comparative transition method\' (discussed in Chapter 13B of the Handbook), only the Questions and Examples related to adopting Topic 842 using the \'effective date transition method\' (included in Chapter 13A of the Handbook) have been reproduced in this Hot Topic The questions included in this Hot Topic may not address all of the issues a lessee could encounter on these topics when transitioning to Topic 842 We encourage entities to discuss these issues with their auditors or other accounting body.raw: {"user_query":"How do companies disclose material weaknesses in internal controls in SEC filings?","conversation_key":"recent-2410-2c82-da93-5dca","history_dump":"[{\"query\":\"How do companies disclose material weaknesses in internal controls in SEC filings?\",\"chat_history\":\"\",\"conversation_key\":null,\"is_sql\":false,\"ques_id\":\"57f3-7342\",\"category\":\"GENERAL\",\"model\":\"perplexity\",\"version\":\"\",\"type\":\"sent\",\"reqTime\":\"2025-11-12T11:15:05.225Z\"},{\"data\":\"**Companies are required to publicly disclose all material weaknesses in internal controls over financial reporting in their SEC filings, specifically in annual (Form 10-K) and quarterly (Form 10-Q) reports.**\\n\\n**Key details:**\\n\\n- **Disclosure location:** Material weaknesses must be reported in the sections of Form 10-K and 10-Q that discuss management's assessment of the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting[3][4][6][13][15].\\n \\n- **Disclosure content:** The disclosure should identify the existence of the material weakness, provide sufficient detail for investors to understand the nature, cause, and impact, and may also describe proposed or ongoing remedial actions to address the weakness[5][6][14].\\n\\n- **Obligation for transparency:** Management must disclose *all* material weaknesses, not just significant deficiencies. A significant deficiency, on its own, does not require public disclosure unless it aggregates with others to create a material weakness, in which case disclosure of the material weakness (including relevant significant deficiencies) is required[1][2].\\n\\n- **Timing:** Disclosure is required in the fiscal period in which the material weakness is identified, so investors and regulators are made aware promptly[11][12][17].\\n\\n- **Auditor involvement:** The company's independent auditor must communicate material weaknesses to the audit committee. If the auditor’s attestation reaches a different conclusion from management’s report, this does not automatically trigger a public disagreement disclosure unless it results in auditor resignation or dismissal[1][2][10].\\n\\n- **Legal basis:** These requirements are grounded in SEC rules, such as Regulation S-K Item 308[13][15], as well as Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act[11].\\n\\nFailure to disclose material weaknesses, or only disclosing without meaningful remediation, can lead to regulatory action and undermine investor confidence[6][14].\\n\\n**Sources:**\\n\\n- [1] https://www.sec.gov/info/accountants/controlfaq0604.htm\\n - [2] https://www.sec.gov/oca/controlfaq1004\\n - [3] https://www.mossadams.com/articles/2025/04/material-weaknesses-in-public-companies\\n - [4] https://www.zuora.com/glossary/material-weakness/\\n - [5] https://www.willkie.com/publications/2007/08/sec-defines-material-weakness-and-gives-guidance__\\n - [6] https://www.corporatesecuritieslawblog.com/2019/02/material-weaknesses-icfr/\\n - [7] https://www.sec.gov/newsroom/speeches-statements/munter-statement-assessing-materiality-030922\\n - [8] https://pathlock.com/learn/4-types-of-internal-controls-weaknesses-and-5-ways-to-fix-them/\\n - [9] https://www.pwc.com/us/en/services/consulting/deals/library/ipo-material-weakness.html\\n - [10] https://lsbe.d.umn.edu/sites/lsbe.d.umn.edu/files/example_2.doc\\n - [11] https://www.floqast.com/blog/how-to-avoid-material-weaknesses-in-sox-compliance\\n - [12] https://www.safepaas.com/articles/what-is-a-material-weakness-in-sec-filings/\\n - [13] https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/17/229.308\\n - [14] https://www.aptitudesoftware.com/blog/material-weakness-trends-implications/\\n - [15] https://dart.deloitte.com/USDART/home/publications/deloitte/icfr/evaluate-remediate-internal-control-deficiencies-material-weakness-significant-deficiency\\n - [16] https://pcaobus.org/oversight/standards/auditing-standards/details/AS2201\\n - [17] https://mendoza.nd.edu/news/time-is-on-managements-side-study-shows/\",\"type\":\"received\",\"is_clarified\":true,\"is_markdown\":true,\"thread_id\":null,\"dislike\":false,\"like\":false,\"receivedTime\":\"2025-11-12T11:15:07.495Z\",\"saved\":true,\"saved_conversation_key\":\"\",\"isStatus\":false,\"isStreaming\":false,\"file_data\":[],\"conversation_id\":\"recent-2410-2c82-da93-5dca\",\"trace_id\":\"6de6152c792a743d13314fdfaac13b0e\",\"is_formatted\":true,\"formatted_data\":\"\",\"thinkingText\":\"Formatting data...\"}]","config":"{\"data\":{\"category\":\"GENERAL\",\"model\":\"perplexity\",\"version\":\"\"},\"type\":\"SEARCH\"}","category":"GENERAL","sub_category":""}
